title: Lens images - objects at 2f and 1-point-5 f

content.question: An object is placed on the principal axis of a convex lens of focal length <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math>, as shown in the figure. The object, represented by the arrows in the figure, is first at location <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>X</mtext></math> at a distance of <math alttext="2 f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>f</mi></math> from the lens, and the resulting image has a height of magnitude <math alttext="h sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>h</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub></math>. The object is then moved to location <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Y</mtext></math> at a distance of <math alttext="1.5 f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.5</mn><mi>f</mi></math> from the lens, and the resulting image has a height of magnitude <math alttext="h sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>h</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>. What is the ratio <math alttext="Ratio h sub Y, to h sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>h</mi><mtext>Y</mtext></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mi>h</mi><mtext>X</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>?

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
